translated: Brahma Heaven Selecting the Ground Method
Carefully according to the Sutra of the Great Brahma Heaven King's Inner Secret, it says: When the Tathagata was on the cause ground, in five

hundred thousand lives as a mantra-holding sage, he often traveled to various mountains and secluded pure rooms, always feeling the Brahma Heaven coming to serve and guard, and also the eight divisions of the heavenly dragons coming to manifest their bodies. Although there were good signs, they were still disturbed by demons, and the Dharma affairs were not accomplished. Sometimes the mantra recitation was not in accordance with the Brahma Heaven;
sometimes it was the method of the mother-to-be;
sometimes the maá¹‡á¸ala could not find the ground, and because of this method, it was often not accomplished.

Now according to the sÅ«tra, there are forty-two kinds of selecting the ground method suitable for making maá¹‡á¸alas, enabling the mantra holders to accomplish the Dharma as they wish. Those who do not obtain this method will in vain consume the days and months.
First:
Entering a deep mountain stone cave, with stones on the four sides and soil in the center, like a place where a person sweeps the ground, this is where the sages attain enlightenment.
In the center of the ground, there are unusual flowers growing. This ground is the best. If one sets up an altar here and recites mantras, one will definitely receive the response of the TathÄgatas.
A bhiká¹£u who upholds the precepts can obtain this ground method, but one who does not uphold the precepts cannot obtain it on this ground. Be careful.
Second:
In a deep mountain, there is a place where a large animal or a lion sits. The ground there is bare and must be a place where sages have sat.
All the animals are spirit guardians of the stÅ«pa. If one sets up an altar on this ground, the Dharma practice will be accomplished.

In the fifth year of Kaihuang, I entered Guangzhou. In a deep mountain, there was this kind of ground. According to the previous method, I received and upheld it. There was a person whose body was golden in color, wearing white clothes, a great spirit, three zhang tall, and so on. I was frightened. The person said:
I am the spirit of the Great Buddha's Crown. Now I see you sitting on a blessed ground, and I manifest my body to receive your Dharma.
Third:
Enter the mountain and go to the high peak. See a large stone as clear as a mirror. See the reflection of a person. This stone is the auspicious stone of the sages.
Take white grass to make a mat. Sit in the northwest corner and recite the mantra to practice the method. Achieve success. Only a fully ordained monk who keeps the precepts can sit.
Fourth:

On the four sides of the mountain, there are grasses, trees, and forests. In the center, there are no objects. Clean like a person sweeping the ground. Make an altar and it will definitely be accomplished.
Fifth:
In the mountain, see a five-colored stone. Blue, yellow, red, white, and black each in its own direction. This is where the sages studied the Way.
This place must be superior. Make an altar and the Four Heavenly Kings will come by themselves.
Sixth:

Enter the mountain and see a coiled stone with horns on the snake's head. Where the snake lies, there is no grass. When it sees a person coming, it gets up and leaves. This is the best place to make an altar.
Seventh:
In the mountains, one sees a white deer lying on the ground, with no grass or trees within a zhang on all four sides, and this place is also suitable for building an altar.
Eighth:
In the mountains, one sees where a white deer lies, with no grass or trees on all four sides. Seeing these signs is a place for building an altar.
Ninth:

In the mountains, there is a person over one zhang tall, wearing black clothes, with four eyes on the face, sitting on a stone. On the stone, the face of a person is clearly seen. If the bhiká¹£u ascends, it will surely be accomplished.
Tenth:

In the mountains, there is an old man with white hair, his eyebrows and beard all white, his eyes following where the person is going. The ground does not grow grass or trees. This place is suitable for building an altar, but if there is grass or trees, it is not suitable.
Eleventh:
In the mountains, one sees a stone or in the soil, five-colored clouds emerge, not seen when it is cloudy or raining. This place must be where sages sit, and building an altar there is excellent.
Twelfth:
In the mountains there is a stone chamber, inside of which lions and fierce beasts dwell, no grass or trees grow, this place is suitable for making an altar.
The thirteenth:
In the mountains there is a flat place without grass, the ground has human footprints one foot in size or larger, suitable for making an altar.
The fourteenth:
Entering a mountain valley, seeing grass growing on the ground, each resembling a person sitting on top, the tips of the grass drooping down, that is suitable.
The fifteenth:
Ascending to the top of the mountain and the flat areas below, seeing strange flowers appearing on all four sides, with an empty area in the center of eight feet or more, that place is excellent.
The sixteenth:

In the mountains, seeing a place where flowers appear, it is the place where sages sit, with strange flowers appearing in all four seasons of spring, summer, autumn, and winter, only having flowers that appear differently from other flowers, that place is excellent.
The seventeenth:
In the mountains, while holding mantras, if white light is seen emerging from the ground, with no grass on the four sides, this ground is excellent.
Eighteenth:
In the mountains, if fragrant qi is seen out of season, and the ground also seems to emit smoke, this ground is excellent.
Nineteenth:
In the mountains, if five-colored light emerges from the ground or from rocks, look at the place where it emerges, and the place of emergence is excellent.
Twentieth:
In the mountains, if peacocks or other birds, grass, and various flowers come and gather on the ground, this ground is suitable, and it is the place where sages emerge, and it is excellent.
Twenty-first:
In the mountains, if there is a place with five-colored soil, look at the five-colored light emerging at dawn the next day, and this ground is suitable.
Twenty-second:
In the mountains, if four white cranes are seen sitting facing each other on a grassless spot, this is the ground for establishing the altar.
Twenty-third:
In the mountains, see two trees facing each other, in the middle there is a shape like a human form, the ground is suitable.
Twenty-fourth:
In the mountains, see a yellow ox or a white ox lying on the ground, the ground has no grass growing, like a place swept by a person, the ground is suitable.
Twenty-fifth:
In the mountains, see a stone that sounds like a bell, the place is suitable.
Twenty-sixth:
In the mountains, see a cave, if it has no echo when called, it is excellent, if it has an echo, it is not.
Twenty-seventh:
In the mountains, there is a temple, the ground is flat, before sunrise, if one sees five-colored light, it is suitable.
Twenty-eighth:
In the mountains, see a divine person wearing heavenly clothes, the place where it appears, is suitable.
Twenty-ninth:
In the mountains, there is soil like an anthill, up to five feet high, it is suitable.
Thirtieth:
In the mountains, if one sees stones or earth shaped like dragons, or if the ground resembles a painted place, it is suitable.
Thirty-first:
In the mountains, if one sees sages or horned humans or beasts, looking at the place where they emerge, it is suitable.
Thirty-second:
At an improper time or place, if there is suddenly light, or if one violates the fire;
or if there is fragrant smoke, this is the place where arhats attain the Way, and it is suitable.
Thirty-third:
If one enters a temple or makes an altar in a layperson's home, it is not a hundredth or a thousandth as good as in the mountains. If one wishes to save sentient beings, one must choose a site.

Above the temple or monastery, dig two feet deep into the ground. If bones are found inside, it is definitely unsuitable. If tiles or stones are found, bury seven precious substances in the ground, and then it may be used.
Thirty-fourth:
Dig three feet deep into the ground and find a few unusual objects or treasures, then it is called an excellent site and is suitable.
Thirty-fifth:
Dig the ground two feet deep, if there are no objects in the ground, make an altar. The soil taken from the ground should be carefully sifted and mixed with incense powder to make a mound.
Thirty-sixth:
The ground has never been inhabited or slept on by people, this ground is suitable.
Thirty-seventh:
The ground has never been used to store grain, firewood, or as a kitchen, nor has it been used as a sleeping place for chickens or dogs, it is suitable.
Thirty-eighth:
At five o'clock in the morning, look at the atmosphere in the ground. If there is a black light, it is unsuitable.
If the light comes from outside, it is suitable.
Thirty-ninth:

If an altar is made in a layperson's home, it is often not in accordance with the Dharma, causing harm. Neither the mantra master nor the other party will benefit. It is only necessary to establish a boundary, not to make an altar. The poor monk has verified that there have been losses.
Fortieth:

If it is necessary to set up an altar, have the patient purify themselves, bathe daily, wear new clean clothes, sit in a separate room, and the mantra master choose a site to set up the altar as before, wholeheartedly chanting the name for recitation. Do not allow the patient to see inside the altar.
If you bring the patient inside the altar, it will harm the mantra master.
Forty-first:
If a bhiká¹£u who has taken the precepts recites the mantra and sets up an altar, it is a hundred thousand times better than a layperson;
If you choose a site and set up an altar once, when the world is destroyed by fire, that site will not be destroyed.
Forty-second:
If you set up a water altar, you do not need to set up a boundary. If you choose an excellent site, if you do not obtain that site, there will be no benefit in the end.
The method of choosing a site by BrahmÄ Heaven ends. Lingyun Yun's edition says:
On the 20th day of the second month in the fourth year of the JÅkyÅ era, it was proofread once.
The forty-ninth year of Jingyan
